description.narrative: Communities are stabilized, and trust and confidence between communities is restored, paving the way towards early recovery.

DCPSF är en givarfond som hanteras av UNDP. Fondens strategi är att stödja projekt på gräsrotsnivå som arbetar med de grundläggande orsakerna till konflikterna på lokal nivå i Darfur. Detta gjordes tidigare med syftet att komplettera övergripande fredsprocesser, men detta syfte är övergivits då pågående fredsansatser ej bedöms som trovärdiga. Projekten under DCSPF pågår parallellt med pågående humanitära insatser, där samverkan främst sker genom koordering och utbyte av information om läget i Darfur. DCPSF utgör ett av de få program som stödjer fredsbyggande på lokal nivå i Darfur.
Genom ett årligt ansökningsförfarande där FN organisationer, nationella och internationella NGO's kan ansöka om finansiering, stödjer DCPSF projekt som bidrar till konfliklösningskommitteer som behandlar och försöker lösa potentiella konflikter på lokal nivå; ekonomiska samarbeten mellan samhällen för att minska konflikter; fredlig hantering av naturresurser som delas av flera samhällen; samt att skapa ett nätverk av fredskapande initiativ för att förbereda och stödja en större fredsprocess i Darfur.
För närvarande genomförs 14 projekt under DCSPF. Ett genomsnittsprojekt är c:a 18 månader långt. En ansökningsomgång för nya projekt kommer hållas i början av 2017. Denna ansökningsomgång är under utforming.
Stödet är ett-årigt, då Sida avvaktar nytt strategiuppdrag, samt på grund av att en ny, tredje, fas av DCSPF ska utformas inför 2018. Sida har föreslagit till UNDP att byta avtalsmall till en senare version från 2015, men DCPSF har ännu inte migrerat till den senare versionen meddelar UNDP. Inför den tredje fasen kommer den nya mallen att introduceras.

Darfur Community and Peace Building Fund (DCPSF), phase 2 (2012-2017). A community driven peace and reconciliation initiative. UNDP administers the fund which aims to foster dialogue and funding of small scale peace building initiatives at community level. The support is a second tranche for phase 2, in line with the new Results Strategy for Sudan, 2014-2016.

description.narrative: This Completion Memo (2016-2017) replace the Conclusion of Performance 2017. The DCPSF's work has contributed to pave the way to early recovery and development by helping communities build peace. In 2016, the DCPSF-supported Community Based Reconciliation Mechanisms (CBRMs) managed over 1,951 cases of community disputes, where 1,813 (93%) were successfully resolved. In 2017, 1,959 cases were brought to partners and CBRMs, and of these 1,656 (85%) were resolved. Starting in 2016, a perception survey of the DCPSF is conducted on an annual basis, to assess the target population's overall satisfaction with the projects implemented by the DCPSF. Below follows a selection of key indicators based on the perception surveys from 2016 and 2017: -Of community members surveyed in 2016, 90 percent (93% in 2017) reported they had access to a CBRM, and 93 percent (92% in 2017) reported they were satisfied with the CBRM mechanism in their community. The result met the stipulated target of 90%. Of those who had actually been involved in a dispute in 2017, 97% were "very" or "somewhat" satisfied and 98% considered the dispute resolved thanks to the CBRM. - Approx. 89% (target 80%) of community members stated in 2016 (82% in 2017) a decrease in communal conflicts because of the presence of CBRMs. The survey found variances by states, where West Darfur had a significant lower satisfaction with their CBRMs, and where people in West Darfur also had a lower percentage of members stating cases to be sucessfully resolved. Unfortunately, no analysis or explanation to this is offered in the reporting. - Asked whether trust and confidence between communities has been restored in the last 12 months (2016-2017), 75% (target 90%) of people surveyed felt that trust had increased “a bit” (41%) or “a lot” (33.6%). Furthermore, 68% of people said this was “largely” or “very much” due to the projects that have been implemented by the DCPSF. The effects of the cooperation between communities had in some aspects not reached intended targets; e.g. even though the number of community initiatives taken to deliver collaborative livelyhoods and new- or re-established markets for community cooperation, the percentage of community members stating an increase in economic interventions between communities were lower (66%) than expected (85%).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
